Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Geometric Frontiers in Algorithm Design

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Complex data sets arise in a plethora of application domains from measurements of various physical processes, history of financial transactions, logs of user activity in a network, and so on. The analysis of such data sets is therefore a task of increasing importance for science and engineering. Even though in many applications there is an abundance of such raw inputs, extracting meaningful information can often be a major computational challenge. In most cases, this difficulty is due to the lack of a useful representation of the data.

Over the recent years, geometric methods have become an indispensable tool for overcoming this difficulty. The reason behind this development is the fact that a data set endowed with pairwise similarities can be naturally interpreted as a geometric space. Such data sets include DNA sequences, statistical distributions, collections of news articles, and so on. Under this interpretation, several important data analytic questions can be understood as geometric computational problems. For example, the problem of classification can be expressed as geometric partitioning. Similarly, the problem of fitting a model to set of measurements can be thought of as interpolation in some appropriate geometric space.

In these contexts, the main algorithmic challenges occur in high-dimensional, or more generally, complex metric spaces. This project aims at resolving some of the main problems inherent in the analysis of such geometric data sets, and thus enabling improved solutions for a variety of computational tasks. The project also seeks to use diverse mathematical tools in the setting of geometric data analysis, forging new connections between mathematics and computer science.

The proposed research will be part of the PI's curriculum development, undergraduate and graduate teaching, and educational and outreach activities. It will also provide the set of research problems that will be used for mentoring undergraduate and graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Metric spaces provide a general and powerful language for expressing various data sets. Often, one can map objects into points in some metric space so that similar objects are mapped to nearby points; for instance, words of the English language to vectors in Euclidean space. A low-distortion embedding between two metric spaces is a mapping that approximately preserves the geometry of the input space. The theory of low-distortion embeddings has been the source of numerous algorithmic tools. Unfortunately, there exist data sets that are not symmertic, and thus fail to satisfy the metric condition; for example, in a transportation network, the travel time from point A to point B might differ than the travel time from B to A. The theory of metric embeddings for these more general directed spaces, also known as quasimetric spaces, has been very limited, compared to the symmetric case. This project significantly extended our current geometric toolbox for handling these spaces. As a qonsequence, new algorithms have been obtained for partitioning directed networks.

Apart from the extension of the current geometric toolbox to the directed setting, this project has also focused on the case of "temporal" geometric data sets. These are point clouds that can change over time. This kind of data sets arise naturally in the analysis of high-dimensional time-series data. Most clustering methods deal with the case of static data sets. This project has developed new algorithms for clustering temporal geometric data sets. Our work also extends to the problem of computing a hierarchical clustering of a temporal data set.

The issue of robustness of data-analytic methods was also explored. The project extended certain types of low-distortion embeddings so that they can cope with data sets that have been corrupted with some small fraction of adversarial noise. This model is interesting because it does not rely on any particular statistical assumption on the noise.

The project also lead to new interesting connections between structural graph theory and geometric measure theory. An important parameter for measuring the complexity of a network is called "treewidth". This is a parameter that quantifies the connectivity of a network. Generally, higher connectivity leads to higher computational complexity for analyzing such netwoks. When measuring the complexity of a subset of Euclidean space, a useful parameter is fractal dimension. The project has studied an analogue of Hausdorff dimension that is applicable to discretizations of subsets of Euclidean space. One important finding is a connection between fractal dimension and the treewidth of low-distortion triangulations of a pointset. This connection leads to faster algorithms for problems such as TSP on data sets of low fractal dimension.
